metadata.title: Has Interest in Data Science Peaked Already? | by Georgi Georgiev | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Has Interest in Data Science Peaked Already?
metadata.description: Analysis of 10 years of search interest trends in data science related topics: fastest growing areas, growth patterns, and correlations.

all_paragraphs: I’m fascinated with the insights one can get from Google Trends ever since I used it to predict the results of my country’s national elections in 2009 and the prediction was significantly more accurate than all respectable polls. With just one hour of work I published a prediction which matched the observed outcomes better than what took Gallup and others orders of magnitude more resources to produce.

I am now summoning the power of Google Trends one more time to get the lay of the land of data science by using search interest trends over the past ten years as a proxy. The data is used to examine the following questions:

If these sound like questions you’d like to know more about, read on. The subfields / sub-topics in the analysis are as follows: data science, big data, artificial intelligence, deep learning, machine learning, reinforcement learning, artificial neural network, business analytics, anomaly detection, A/B testing (see technical note 1 for details).
First the basic lay of the land. As Google Trends only allows 5 terms to be compared simultaneously, I have split 9 of the 10 topics into two, grouping them so the trends are visible.

Several insights are readily identifiable. Back in 2010–2011 interest in the ‘artificial neural network’ topic (not shown) was higher than all five shown on the graph, but it was dethroned as early as 2012 and now has the same level of interest as ‘artificial intelligence’. Interest in ‘artificial intelligence’ was also gradually surpassed by all the rest except the newest kid on the block in the face of ‘deep learning’. ‘big data’ first became a thing in 2011. It peaked four years later in 2015 but is now in decline and has been surpassed by both ‘machine learning’ (since 2017) and ‘data science’ (since 2019). Notably, interest in both ‘data science’ and ‘deep learning’ was practically non-existent just 7 years ago as they started getting traction only in 2013–2014.

Things are nowhere near as crazy in the tier with less relative interest which is shown in figure 2. ‘business analytics’, ‘a/b testing’, and ‘anomaly detection’ all exhibit more or less stable growth. ‘reinforcement learning’ is a mild outlier in this group as it seems to follow the growth trend of ‘machine learning’.
Across the whole 10-year period ‘machine learning’ and ‘big data’ were most popular by a large margin, but by 2020 ‘data science’ has taken the second place from ‘big data’.

Figure 3 below combines all ten topics to examine the rates of growth over time (click for full size). Unlike the first two figures, trends in this one are not scaled relatively to each other to allow for a comparison of growth rates.

The general trend is clear — there is a significant growth in interest across the board with some subfields growing faster than others. Notably, even very related subtopics take off at different points and show very different rates of growth across the time series.

Two subfields stand out from the rest upon further analysis. A comparison between the growth rates relative to Jun 2010 of all ten terms (figure below) shows that by far the most growth is seen for the terms ‘data science’ and ‘deep learning’.
The increase is even more startling if we compare the peak versus the starting point:

This is of course partially due to their very low starting point — these two terms were non-existent in 2010 not only relative to their peaks, but also relative to all other terms in the analysis. These are also the terms with the most rapid growth when we take into account how late they appear on the map (also see figure 8). Whether due to more readily available big data, or to the proliferation of software which democratizes access to highly technical instruments, or due to pressure from above to automate, interest in deep learning and data science is growing rapidly over the past ten years, and by a wide margin compared even to other high growth topics.

An examination of the growth of the search interest trends will help answer this question. A rough classification into extreme growth fields (more than four-fold increase) and high growth fields results in the following two graphs:

Figure 6 shows how interest in ‘big data’ is in decline after its spectacular growth in 2011–2013. Other terms have not grown for several years now and only ‘business analytics’ and ‘data science’ seem like they might have more growth ahead. However, both experience a peak in Feb 2020 and a subsequent significant decline. It is reasonable to ask if this is the peak of interest in data science and if so, if we are going to see interest remain on these levels for a while, or if it will enter a slow decline much like ‘big data’.
Another visualization of the stark explosive growth of ‘data science’ and ‘deep learning’ even relative to other very high growth terms is shown on figure 8.

This figure shows the lack of growth of interest in ‘deep learning’ in recent years. Also visible is a break in the rapid growth trend in ‘data science’. My conclusion based on these data is “yes, we have likely reached the peak”.

As I was examining the trend lines it occurred to me they show much less correlated movement than I expected given how tightly related many of these search terms intuitively are. Some fields took off faster than others, and also at different times.

I decided to run a correlation analysis to more formally examine these relationships or lack thereof. The raw search interest data was detrended using first order differencing, resulting in a stationary series. Initially I used Pearson’s correlation coefficient and noticed a number of coefficients in the 0.6–0.7 range. Upon further examination these turned out to be mostly due to outliers. As the relationship might also be non-linear, I decided to use Kendall’s tau rank coefficient instead of Pearson’s. These are more robust to outliers and would capture any type of monotone relationships, not just linear ones (see technical note 2). Kendall’s tau is somewhat less powerful though.

The correlations were computed using this correlation coefficient calculator I’ve coded which also provides accompanying statistics. The p-values for many of the correlations were very small and the 95% confidence intervals quite narrow suggesting genuine relationships.

The resulting correlation matrix shows that search interest for the different topics is not nearly as related as one might expect. The largest correlation is 0.56 and it is between ‘deep learning’ and ‘machine learning’. A few others are in the 0.4–0.5 range, but most are lower.

It seems ‘machine learning’ correlates the most with all other search topics, whereas ‘business analytics’ correlates the least. ‘data science’ shows positive correlations across the board, but these are slightly weaker compared to those of ‘machine learning’. Search interest in ‘artificial intelligence’ exhibits low correlation with the rest, and so does the interest in ‘reinforcement learning’. The remainder show coefficients mostly in the 0.2–0.4 range.

Data science topics exhibit impressive growth in interest over the past decade. ‘data science’ and ‘deep learning’ in particular exhibit astonishing levels of growth between 2010 and 2020. In just a few short years they make the journey from near non-existence to leading topics in terms of search interest.

That said, it seems interest in most data science topics have already peaked. For some the peak was as early as 2015, while for others it was much sooner. Though we might see a recovery in the rest of 2020, the trend of rapid growth for ‘data science’ which was established in 2013 is surely broken.

A correlation analysis found interest in most sub fields to be loosely to moderately related with the highest correlation coefficients being around 0.5. This shows that the data science field is quite diverse, and each sub field has more or less a life of its own, with its own periods of glory and decline.
